Problem:
Consider a linear system governed by the following operator equation \( \mathcal{L}(x) = D^2x + 2x \) where \( D \) represents the differential operator with respect to variable \( t \). Assess how the introduction of a Laplace transformation \( \mathcal{F}(x(t)) = \int_0^\infty e^{-st}x(t) \, dt \) modifies the system.

If the system is subjected to an additional transformation \( \mathcal{G}(x(t)) = \int_0^\infty e^{-pt}x(t) \, dt \) at \( t_1 > 0 \), will the subsequent behavior of \( x(t) \) for \( t > t_1 \) be independent of the initial Laplace transformation?
Explanation: The introduction of \( \mathcal{G} \) as a new transformation combines with the effects of the existing Laplace transformation (if it was applied). The interplay between \( \mathcal{F} \) and \( \mathcal{G} \) can result in a composite transformation effect, which makes the behavior of \( x(t) \) dependent on both.
